reasoning: The critique targets a real junction in the essay: the move from (i) pluralism/no-safe-option across moral perspectives to (ii) a formal comparison of “fussiness” across “plausible moral views” using VNM-style expected utility and intertheoretic aggregation (Sections 3–3.5). If that move failed, it would significantly weaken the paper’s intended implication that default survival doesn’t reliably yield mostly-great futures (since the paper explicitly leans on claims about what “most plausible views” imply). However, the position does not purely rest on cross-view aggregation: Section 2 also aims to show, within many individual perspectives, that single non-obvious flaws can destroy a large fraction of value (“fragility”/multiplicative factors), so the thesis can survive as a within-view claim even if cross-view comparability is messier. The critique’s main charge of self-undermining is only partly successful because the essay itself already flags representation limits and moral uncertainty problems (completeness/VNM restrictions, intertheoretic comparison thorniness), and the argument in 3 is largely conditional (“on plausible easygoing/fussy views, X follows”) rather than requiring robust aggregation to get any conclusion. Still, it is correct that if one relaxes VNM comparability substantially, the quantitative fussiness apparatus loses force, and the policy-guidance bite becomes more viewpoint-relative. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little fluff, but it overstates the dilemma (“abandon diversity or collapse”) since the author can consistently: (a) treat pluralism as object-level disagreement about value while (b) still restricting analysis to a representable subset for tractability, and (c) draw conditional/agent-relative conclusions under moral uncertainty without claiming a unique all-things-considered aggregation.
title: The pluralism argument undermines the shared expected-utility framework it requires
